fields.description:
Sometimes, when a job in my build fails, I know as soon as it has failed that I want to run it again (e.g., dependency on external infrastructure that was down at the time the job ran, but is fixed now).

In some cases, other longer-running jobs are still in progress, so the "Rerun Failed Jobs" button doesn't appear. This means that I need to wait for everything else to finish before I have a chance to rerun the job that has already failed.

It would be better if I could kick off another run of jobs that have already failed while other jobs are still in progress.
fields.summary: Rerun failed jobs while build is still in progress

fields.description:
Commit messages are not word-wrapped or truncated causing text to overlap when viewing the dashboard, causing it to overlap the favorite plans column.

I committed a changeset with this test message:
{noformat}
Testing huge commit message /dir1/dir2/dir3/dir4/dir5/dir6/dir7/dir8/dir9/dir10/dir11/dir12/dir13/dir14/dir15/dir16/dir17/dir18/dir19/dir20/dir21/dir22/dir23/dir24/dir25/dir26/dir27/dir28/dir29/dir30/NewFile.java
{noformat}

The result can be seen in the screenshot attached (Overlap.jpg).

The same error happens in Google Chrome 17.0.963.83 and Internet Explorer 9.0.8112.16421, but *does not happen* in Firefox 11.0 (No_Overlap.jpg).
fields.summary: Commit messages overlap when viewing the dashboard
"Block build if parent plans have unbuilt changes" doesn't block when running Manual builds

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo will throw the following error in the log:
{code}
2012-04-01 09:12:23,024 INFO [TP-Processor3] [AccessLogFilter] arjans GET https://bamboo.luminis.net/rest/api/latest/server?_=1333264343127 362321kb
2012-04-01 09:12:27,195 ERROR [elastic-pool-3-thread-1] [EBSVolumeManagerImpl] Could not retrieve volume descriptions.
com.xerox.amazonws.ec2.EC2Exception: Client error : AWS was not able to validate the provided access credentials
	at com.xerox.amazonws.ec2.Jec2.makeRequestInt(Jec2.java:2006)
	at com.xerox.amazonws.ec2.Jec2.describeVolumes(Jec2.java:1511)
	at com.atlassian.aws.ec2.EBSVolumeManagerImpl.run(EBSVolumeManagerImpl.java:67)
	at com.atlassian.aws.ec2.UpdateSchedulerImpl.run(UpdateSchedulerImpl.java:45)
	at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:441)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask$Sync.innerRunAndReset(FutureTask.java:317)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.runAndReset(FutureTask.java:150)
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.access$101(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:98)
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.runPeriodic(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:180)
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:204)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.runTask(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:886)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:908)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:662)
{code}

+Steps to replicate the problem+
# Install a new fresh Bamboo
# Login to Bamboo and direct your to Elastic configuration via _Bamboo Administration >> Elastic Bamboo >> Configuration_ 
# On the configuration page for elastic agent, do not fill in anything and just click on Save button
# The exception will be throw
# Disable the Elastic configuration 

+Workaround+
# Stop Bamboo
# Find the  administration.xml via _<bamboo home>\xml-data\configuration_
# Delete the tag including everything in between the following tag:
{code}
<elasticConfig>
......
</elasticConfig>
{code}
# Save the changes and restart Bamboo server

*NOTE:* Please backup your administration.xml before you proceed with the deletion
fields.summary: Bamboo throw exception to the log every minutes when Elastic configuration is not configure correctly

(should be the same as the one in the Child Pages: http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO40/Users+and+permissions)
fields.summary: Bamboo documentation link is incorrect

fields.description:
Nowadays it is possible to allow / deny access to 'All logged in users' and to 'Anonymous users' so they can / can't access the whole instance.

However, it is impossible to allow / deny access to plans in the moment of plan creation.

It would be awesome to have the possibility of creating plan templates which would include permissions, and to choose a template when creating plans, and modify whatever is needed.

A suggestion is to have the plan template configuration page under Plans submenu, and every time someone wants to create a plan, there should be a chance to choose a template and modify it.
fields.summary: Add possibility to create plan templates and choose a template when creating a plan

fields.description:

The list is limited to Mercurial Repos and Fisheye for Mercurial

But the only option for GIT is to have Fisheye - we should give users ability to configure GITHub as their web-repository.

I'm able to log into GitHub with this user account and access repositories.

- save

fields.summary: Update documentation for export/import plan configuration

fields.description:
I'm not sure if this is applicable, so if someone find this issue wrong - please 'wontfix' it.

Lets assume we have a Git repository hosted via ssh:// protocol. Access to that repository is via the ssh (rsa) private/public key authentication. Lets assume the repo contain submodules. So for example we have in .submodules
{noformat}
[submodule "submodules/core"]
	path = submodules/core
	url = ssh://git.company.com/projects/core.git
{noformat}
(where our repository is under ssh://git.company.com/projects/product.git)

In such scenario Bamboo Agents will do:
1) fetch the data from ssh://d73ceba5-2327-4e81-8c63-f61ad3024bc3@127.0.0.1:58505/projects/product.git --PROXIED-> ssh://git.company.com/projects/product.git to agent's Job working directory
2) bamboo issues "git submodule init; git submodule update" commands.
3) thus git notices there are some submodules defined (in "workDir/.submodules" file)
4) git will execute another fetch, this time from ssh://git.company.com/projects/core.git and will put it under ./submodules/core directory _(note that here it is the Git that deduces the correct url from .submodules file, not the Bamboo)_.
5) finish (update the workspace, index, etc)

Now, problem is in step (4) - it won't go through Bamboo SSH proxy, and as it won't be proxied the Bamboo user will have to setup all Bamboo Agents correctly (with .ssh/config files and rsa-identity files). This can be PITA. Would be good if somehow Bamboo would work with submodules in more transparent way so the Bamboo user wouldn't have to do the setup manually.
fields.summary: If I want to use git submodules then I shouldn't have to upload and configure SSH keys on each Bamboo Agent.

fields.description:
I really like a lot Bamboo, I used it several years with J2EE development. Now that I have switched to growing and exciting Django + Phython world, I found of course few support behind it.

I have found some bits and pieces at:
   http://reinout.vanrees.org/weblog/2011/06/07/bitbucket.html
   http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1419629/atlassian-bamboo-with-django-python-possible
   http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=45982
   https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/35809/how-to-parse-django-tests-with-bamboo


Things that I imagine for nice Django + Python support would be:
# main Know-how / guide page for Django + Python under Bamboo
# Test results integration and recommended test frameworks.
# pep8 integration  (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pep8)
# pyflakes integration  (https://launchpad.net/pyflakes)
# PyLint integration (http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pylint)
# Nice Reporting integration from all those valuable 3rd party.


If this feature would be added, it will immediately mean a "BUY" decision for my company.  In the meantime I have good old Jenkins.

I also think there are quite a lot of projects/companies for such nice feature.

Also check https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15809
fields.summary: robust Django / Python support

fields.description:
A number of OnDemand builds on BEAC are not collecting artifacts. It seems like the second stage of builds never collects artifacts.

https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/JST-JSTGIT13-1/artifact (Was a 2 stage build, now reverted back to 1 stage)
https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/JST-JSTGIT19-1/artifact
fields.summary: Manual & restarted stages of chain branches not collecting artifactspplication links in Application Trust modes with explicit 443 port fail to authenticate

fields.description:
In a multi-module Maven build, if a module have a test name that matches a name in another module, Bamboo will:

1. Display the wrong number of tests, as the same name for both tests will counted only once.
2. Display the results for only one of the tests. When reading the result files, Bamboo overwrite the already scaned results for a test with the results of the next test scanned with the same name.

Bamboo will always display the results for the last test scanned, but it is not possible to determine which test will be the last one.
fields.summary: Bamboo counts and displays only once, tests with the same name in different Maven modules

fields.description:
It seems that the 'obsoletion' mechanism from Amazon Linux collided with update mechanism from CentOS (the source of our Firefox package)...
It's probably best to try to run Ubuntu based Selenium image, at least we will not have to mix and match packages from two distros with unsynchronised update cycles. This will also let us test the Ubuntu scripts.
fields.summary: Fix SAL tests on Tardigrade, again

fields.description:
Currently if you attempt to start a build while there are already the maximum number of builds running, you get an error.

It would be nice, at least for some use cases, to be able to queue the build, but not start it yet.  I think I'm asking for a true "Concurrency limit", and the addition of a new "Queue limit".

This would be especially useful for integrations - e.g. Matt Watson's Review Build plugin.  I want to start a build on my branch, but we already have 4 running.  I'm probably going to forget to start it later.  Or even if I do remember, I'll have to wait longer than I need to before merging my branch (because the build wasn't started as early as it could have been).  This is causing context-switching for me.
fields.summary: Allow a build queue to grow past the "Concurrent Builds" limit
Upgrade to Amazon Linux 2012.09.1

fields.description:
I keep finding that I'm selecting capabilities by accident which are only configured on disabled elastic bamboo image configurations and/or disabled agents.

For example, the default windows image has "JDK 1.6.0_29" and even though I've disabled that configuration, when selecting a JDK in Maven 3.x builder for example, this value still shows up in that list.

Since I can't actually delete the stock images, I'm forced to go and remove all of the capabilities from them to avoid folks accidentally using a capability which is only available on a disabled configuration.
fields.summary: Disabled agents or image configurations should not contribute capabilities to select in the UI

fields.description:

It should be possible to save the IM address for the user locally - as Crowd doesn't support custom user attributes anyway, so there is no way to store the IM address in Crowd.
fields.summary: Can't set IM address for an Crowd user

fields.description:
1. Configure plan branches: set "automatic branch detection" to on, input something into "Only create branches..." field. For example "test.*"
2. save.
3. Go to source Repositories, default repository, change it's repositoryUrl (I assume it is git/hg repository).
4. Save. (It doesn't matter if you change to something valid - just repositoryUrl must differ)
5. Go to plan's Branches configuration.
6a. Automatic Branch Detection is off. If you tick it - you will see the "Only create branches..." field is still "text.*".
6b. While I expected ABD to be still turned on.

----

I think the problem is in the (I wrote it) BAM-10613 - if you edit default repository then the autodetection should turn off if new repository does *not* support branch detection. Apparently I must have skewed the logic, somewhere around [lines 226-240 of RepositoryConfigurationServiceImpl.java|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bamboo/src/127c221c01e1/components/bamboo-core/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bamboo/repository/RepositoryConfigurationServiceImpl.java#cl-226]
fields.summary: Changing repository url turns off the "automatic branch detection".

fields.description:
https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-6845

Bug 1: Upgrade task 2707 
Job tries to checkout not-existing Default repository.
Scenario when it can happen:
- Plan's repository  set to None
- Several Jobs defining it's own repos.
- A Job _not_ defining repo

It's quite complicated: repos from jobs are moved to plan. Code which decides if job needs checkout task checks if there is plan repository which is not 'None' - after moving a job repository there is. So it creates checkout task for the job and, as it doesn't have its own repo, it uses default. Later on the None repository is removed.

Bug 2: Upgrade 2708: Removal of None repository does not update position in PlanRepositoryLinks
fields.summary: bugs in upgrade tasks: 2707 and 2708

fields.description:
Hi,

We have Jira, Confluence, Crowd, Bamboo, Fisheye all running behind a reverse proxy (apache httpd). We would like to log the currently authenticated user in the logs of apache, instead of having 5 different tomcat valve logs with that information.

Would you please add this information in a response header - obviously, for simplicity, the same header name across all Atlassian apps would be welcome.

Thank you
--
Issa
fields.summary: Add authenticated user in http response headers for logging ability in reverse proxy

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability in Bamboo that results from the way third-party XML parsers are used in Bamboo.

This vulnerability allows an attacker to:

*    Execute denial of service attacks against the Bamboo server, and
*    Read all local files readable to the system user under which Bamboo runs.

The attacker needs to have an account with the affected Bamboo server instance and be able to log in in order to execute the attack.

All versions of Bamboo up to and including 3.4.4 are affected.

Full details of the severity, risks and vulnerability can be found in the [Bamboo Security Advisory 2012-05-17|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/WgM_EQ].
fields.summary: Bamboo XML Vulnerability

* Link at bottom should be "Configure Branches"
fields.summary: Handle Dashboard branch dropdown when there are no branches

fields.description:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Setting+up+Build+Dependencies suggests that for dependent plans, revisions are preserved. With the advent of multiple repositories, it is not obvious that this is only the case *only if the repository sets of both plans are the same*, i.e. they need to have the same set of repositories, and the same credentials.

We were tripped up by this with dependent plans, but the dependent plan having an additional repository. Even though there were other common repositories, the revisions for these common repositories were not preserved. I would have expected the revisions for the common repositories to be preserved. 

A workaround exists to have the same repository sets for the triggering plan and dependent plan, but it is not obvious and doesn't seem to be documented anywhere.
fields.summary: When triggering dependent builds, repository revisions for common repositories are not preserved

fields.description:
If you are running bamboo on port 443. and you create an application link from JIRA using the url https://server:443/bamboo, authentication fails with an error "Bad URL Signature" recorded in the log, and the jira user can only see jobs in bamboo available to anonymous users.

Changing the application link to https://server/bamboo resolves the problem.
fields.summary: Application links in Application Trust modes with explicit 443 port fail to authenticate

fields.description:
Provide non-administrator ability to administer agents, this should allow non-admin users to:

# Configure capabilities 
# Monitor agent uptime
# Configure Agents
fields.summary: Agent Administrator

fields.description:
When -Dmaven.test.redirectTestOutputToFile=true (or equiv plugin configuration) on surefire/failsafe, test output is collected into a <FQCN>-output.txt file.

This output can contain critical details to determine why a test failed or to ensure what a test did was expected.  The bamboo test result collector and report generator really should include these details.

Currently the work-around is to make an artifact which collects **/*-reports/*.txt and then manually correlate test to its output file... which is a PITA.
fields.summary: Capture surefire/failsafe test output.txt when collection test results

fields.description:
Add in a "not" component to specifying agent requirements in a job.

Example:
"I want an agent that I can compile 32 bit builds on, but is not a 64bit machine. It must be explicitly a 32 bit operating system"

supports32bit exists
supports64bit does not exists

Example:
"I want an agent that isn't a CentOS 5.3 machine, but is fine for every other version of CentOS"

Operating_System does not equal CentOS 5.3   (this would allow for agents of CentOS 5.5, 6.0, etc)
fields.summary: Allow a job requirement for Not Equals and Not Exists

fields.description:
There are some issues when attempting to specify and use empty values for agent capabilities. You can specify a new agent custom capability and not give it any value, and it's used correctly in build plans through ${bamboo.capability.variable}. However you can not edit a custom capability of an agent that already exists and change it to an empty value. You get an error saying that there must be a value. Also in a Job's requirements, you can't specify a agent capability that equals an empty value.

Empty values for agent capabilities have merit with certain situations and should be fully supported by bamboo. For instance if you have many agents with various GCC versions installed. The plan you are working on may require gcc4.1.2, but depending on the agent, the gcc4.1.2 command can be different if the suffix for the command was setup differently. One can use the value of a gcc capability specification to know what suffix that particular agent has for that specific version of GCC

Example:

Agent A Capabilities and Values and actual box commands
gcc412  -  value:      -   Actual Command: gcc
gcc346  -  value: 34   -   Actual Command: gcc34
gcc445  -  value: 445  -   Actual Command: gcc445

Agent B capabilities and Values
gcc412  -  value: 41   -   Actual Command: gcc41
gcc346  -  value:      -   Actual Command: gcc
gcc445  -  value: 44   -   Actual Command: gcc44

executing the "gcc" command on Agent A and Agent B would result in different compiler versions being use. if my plan wants gcc 4.1.2, and it has the capability of running on multiple agents that may not use the same gcc command for 4.1.2 the bamboo.capability.variable setup works nicely for this.

CC=gcc${bamboo.capability.gcc412} CXX=g++${bamboo.capability.gcc412}

and the correct suffix is substituted for that agent it's running on. Since most Linux setups have a "Default" gcc version that used no suffix, specifying an empty value for that agent's capabilities comes in handy.
fields.summary: Issues with Agent capabilities when the value is empty
Input more information in "Setting up Build Dependencies" page

fields.description:
Consider the following scenario. 

Bamboo is running on an internal network at address 192.168.0.100:8085. The network is connected to the internet via a NAT firewall with an externally facing ip address of bamboo.mycompany.com. A NAT routing has been set up on the firewall to redirect traffic to bamboo.mycompany.com:80 to 192.168.0.100:8085

For this to work, and for people to be able to access bamboo at http://bamboo.mycompany.com/bamboo the base URL in the server settings is set to http://bamboo.mycompany.com/bamboo.

However, when the Elastic Agent tries to establish a connect to the Bamboo server via the ssh server it attempts to connect to bamboo.mycompany.com:80. Unfortunately the end point of the ssh tunnel is on the server at 192.168.0.100 and because of NAT this machine cannot access bamboo.mycompany.com:80 so the tunnel times out.

The solution would be for the agent to attempt to connect to the actual ip address/port of the bamboo server and not to the base URL settings.
fields.summary: Elastic Agent Connections time out during creation if using Bamboo behind NAT firewall

fields.description:
There I uses the newer features like Stages and having many jobs inside of stages quite a lot.

It works quite well when doing a complete production build. If something fails in between I can try to fix things and hit the "Rerun Failed Jobs".

But I would need the functionality to run individual jobs on demand, not only the complete build or the "failed" jobs.

Why would this be important:

1) for testing purposes. When setting up/maintaining such a build it takes too long to restart the complete build for just seeing whether one special job is working well. In theory it would be possible to disable all jobs not needed for that testrun, but with that many jobs this is not a really practical solution.

2) sometimes we only need special parts of the complete build.
Doing a complete build takes lots of time (up to 24h in this example) and wastes lots of resources. Here it would be possible to duplicate those jobs that might be used alone, but this also is not very practical as one would have to maintain to many builds in parallel.

So it would be very helpful to get the possibility to have a possibility to start individual jobs of a complex build.
fields.summary: Manual execution of jobs even when jobs don't fail

fields.description: plan variables seem to be generally expandable.  Not so for include/exclude options in advanced confiuration of a source repo (svn and git would be obvious candidates among others).  Plan variables drastically minimize re-inventing the wheel in creating bamboo plans.  Due to the difficulty in re-creating plans in any automated fashion, allowing for plan variable abstraction in all facets of creating a bamboo plan appears desirable.
fields.summary: support variable expansion in include/exclude advanced option for source repository

fields.description: When a plugin developer creates a custom result tab following the available documentation, the gui is broken when switching between jobs.  The url is not properly updated when query strings are used for custom actions.  The javascript used to update the links in the Plan Navigator assumes that the url will contain the buildResultKey ($plankKey-$buildKey-$buildNumber) but this is not the case when using query strings which take the form of buildKey=${buildKey}&buildNumber=${buildNumber}.
fields.summary: Ability to create custom result tabs is broken in the gui.

fields.description: As long as a push or a merge failed for 'regular' reasons (i.e. newer changesets were detected in the destination or a merge conflict has ocurred), we should not spam logs with stack traces, ERRORs and WARNs.
fields.summary: Better error handling for failed pushes and merges

fields.description:
On our CAV-GITVM plan on BEAC, we have the 'Only run Build if other Plans are currently passing' option enabled and we cannot disable it.

If you uncheck the checkbox and hit save, the page comes back with the checkbox enabled.

!https://img.skitch.com/20120322-b8x6kerbghx2et9jrd1d422dek.jpg!
fields.summary: Cannot uncheck the 'Only run Build if other Plans are currently passing'

fields.description: Please pick this up once Paul has attached the new help properties file.
fields.summary: Update help path references

fields.description:
# CD results should be cached for a short while (like 60 seconds)
# "hg --version" / "git --version" nonsense should be removed
fields.summary: ChangeDetection for Git should be modified to lower the pressure on Bamboo server/VCS servers

fields.description:
When people move Bamboo from one user management system to another, all the original author/username links dont exist and Bamboo will not try to recreate them.

I suggest adding two operations. 
# Ability to unlink all authors
# Ability to attempt to link any currently unlinked authors.
fields.summary: Bulk Author Linking Operations

fields.description:
Its a big pita to create a new elastic image configuration that is similar to another if you have customized the capabilities of the configuration.

It should be possible to clone a copy of an existing configuration.
fields.summary: Allow cloning a copy of a elastic image configuration

fields.description:
Assume that the post commit hook under GitHub is set up to access Bamboo with user 'robotuser'. Let's say user 'joe' commits and pushes to the repository. This triggers an automatic build, however Bamboo marks the build like this:
'This build was manually triggered by robotuser'

Please change the message to state that this was an 'automatically triggered' build. Also, please state which GitHub user has initiated the push.
fields.summary: Change the message for automated build triggered by a GitHub user and specify the user name

fields.description:
We merged from one branch into another and Bamboo got a bit confused about what changes are new:

!after.png!

AFAICT it should have shown 4 commits only:

{noformat}
jira50 (atlassian_jira_5_0_branch) $ git glog 8ca5907..9de34a2 --oneline 
* 9de34a2 (origin/atlassian_jira_5_0_SHIPIT_branch) fixing SHIP_IT branch to pick up REST change
* 0fb6402 Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/atlassian_jira_5_0_1_branch' into atlassian_jira_5_0_SHIPIT_branch
* 3d719fc (origin/atlassian_jira_5_0_1_branch) AUTOCOMMIT update JIRA for next version 5.0.1-SNAPSHOT
* d2a042e JRA-27419 Upgrade rest from 2.5.5-SEC2 to 2.5.5.1 (now in public mvn)
{noformat}

See the screenshots for the 2 relevant builds.
fields.summary: Bamboo "Code Changes" reports 36,479 changes instead of 4

Jens and James will provide a graphic to go inside the dialog

Add export/import to EC2 instance startup scripts

fields.description:
The use case we have is a test load balancer (called Hallelujah) that distributes tests across different agents. Some of the agents run on EC2 while others are "normal ones".

The current approach would scale better if we could make the EC2 ones read from a S3 bucket.

Przemek also mentioned that some customers want to use an NFS volume as the artifact sharing directory.

I noticed that on some screens the Plugin Notification Icon was intefering with the Bamboo UX or was not consistend with other screens (see attachments)

fields.description:
Allow an option so that a build step is conditional on the presence or value of a variable.

A good use case is given here https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/36658/is-it-possible-to-tag-a-bamboo-build-only-if-a-particular-variable-is-set

A variant of this use case would be to run the VCS tagging step only if the {{$\{bamboo.jira.version}}} was set - i.e. tag if the build was initiated from jira as a release, but not if the build was initiated manually or due to a repository update.

h3. Atlassian Update
We have an App that allows this functionality, which can be downloaded from the Atlassian Marketplace here: [Conditional tasks for Bamboo|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1219706/conditional-tasks-for-bamboo?hosting=server&tab=overview]. The App is compatible with Bamboo versions 6.7.1 and above. Please check out the App, and let us know how it works for you!
fields.summary: Conditional build step depending on value (or existence) of variable

fields.description: Implementation note: propably checking if branch is returned by getOpenBranches is enough, watch out for error cases though.
fields.summary: Branch expiry should recognize that branch is closed on vcs side.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In Bamboo, when an application link to JIRA is created using an ApplicationUrl that is not accessible from a browser this breaks the display if the icons for each JIRA Issue that is shown in the Build Results Summary page.

Application links can be configured with an ApplicationUrl that is "internal only", e.g it bypasses the proxy, etc. that is used to provide the BaseUrl used from a browser to access the app.  This is frequently done for performance to reduce load on the proxy and speed up app-to-app communication by avoiding the overhead of SSL.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo 3.4.4, JIRA 5.0 (verification in current versions pending)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Bamboo on a server with a BaseUrl that is accessible from outside the local network.
# Install JIRA on a server with a BaseUrl that is accessible from outside the local network.
# Configure a "private" hostname and port for JIRA which is only accessible from *inside* the local network.
# From Bamboo administration, create an application link to JIRA.
# Set the DisplayUrl to the same as the JIRA BaseUrl and the ApplicationUrl to the private protocol, host, and port:
!ApplicationLink-SplitRouting.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results
# Icon images for JIRA Issues should be retrieved using the DisplayUrl

h3. Actual Results
# Urls for icon images use the ApplicationUrl.  When this URL is not accessible from a browser the icons are not available.

!link.png|thumbnail!
 
h3. Notes

This is a problem with how the Bamboo code utilizes the application link.  Individual features can choose between the BaseUrl, ApplicationUrl, and DisplayUrl when constructing links.  Urls for browser-to-app communication such as links, images, JavaScript, and style sheets should use the DisplayUrl.  URLs for app-to-app communication should use the ApplicationUrl.

h3. Workaround

Configure network appliances to allow access to JIRA application images from outside the private network.  In other words, expose {{APPLICATION_URL/images/*}} to the internet.
fields.summary: Build Results Summary page has broken JIRA Issue icons when the applink ApplicationUrl is not the proxied BaseURL of JIRA

fields.description:
Phase 1
1. Click delete Repo
2. Pop up with a "This repo is being used in 3 tasks in Job A B C, these tasks will need to updated manually. Are you sure you want to delete?" Link to Task would be a nice bonus here

Phase II
2. Becomes "This repo is being used in 3 tasks in Job A B C. You can change to repositiory that it refers to: <selectlist> "
Select list contains "None - requires manual change" plan
fields.summary: Repository remove should handle configuration of tasks depending on it

fields.description:
Steps to recreate:
# start with a plan with a job that already has the "clean working directory after each build" checked
# uncheck it
# save
# ((then it still has it checked and confirmed it does continue to delete the working directory)

Attached are before and after photos.
fields.summary: Unable to uncheck "clean working directory after each build"

fields.description:
We need to run through the entire customisation process for both Linux and Windows and update the documentation to reflect the process.

If we can write any scripts (and host them on bitbucket) that can improve EC2 customisation, we should do this.

Currently its difficult to find out what version of bamboo-elastic-image you need - is it safe to always use the latest? How can the customer find this out?

Please try the process out using the Ubuntu LTS to see if we can shake out any problems we do not see on CENTOS/Fedora
fields.summary: Improve AMI customisation process and documentation

fields.description:
Would really like to see Ubuntu LTS (10.04 LTS and soon 11.04 LTS) based default supported elastic bamboo agent image configurations.

Management of CentOS/RHEL/RPM and Debian/Ubuntu/DEB systems is quite a bit different.  Supporting both major flavors with AmazonLinux/CentOS and Ubuntu would help fill in the gap here and allow shops using Ubuntu to have familiar agent environment.
fields.summary: Support default elastic bamboo linux images based on Ubuntu
Update  image-files.zip to conform with EC2 Linux configuration documentation.

fields.description: Instead of being able to add just 1 capability to an agent at a time and having to jump between different pages on bamboo, why not add capabilities just like you add variables, where you can easily configure agents without jumping between different pages and waiting for your browser to constantly load... would speed up adding a new agent rather quickly
fields.summary: Specify agent capabilities faster

fields.description:
We've got an extremely busy 100-agent server, and we try not to restart it for extended periods of time if we can avoid it.
The Bamboo server process redirects all output to <BAMBOOINSTALLDIR>/logs/bamboo.log
This single log file will be populated without limit until the next time Bamboo is restarted, at which point it will be over-written completely.

There's two problems that need addressing:
# Restarting Bamboo should not wipe out the the existing logs. Right now we have to remember to copy the log before we start Bamboo so as we don't lose it.
# Bamboo is run via the Tanuki wrapper, but bamboo.sh over-rides any logging properties that are set in <BAMBOOINSTALLDIR>/conf/wrapper.conf. We really want to have great control over log roll-over, and wrapper.conf is the most appropriate method to do this. Because all logging is in a single enormous bamboo.log, it makes analysing it and sending it to Atlassian Support a major PITA if the log is a few days old. We really want to be able to roll-over daily.
fields.summary: bamboo.sh over-rides wrapper logging settings preventing <BAMBOOINSTALL>/logs/bamboo.log customization
During s3 sync in elastic agent startup, MD5s for local files should be lazily calculated

fields.description: Currently if git detects that there is a new revision number but then fails to collect changes it puts in a dummy change and the build still continues.  This failed change detection could be indicative of bigger problems and should cause the build to not start at all.
fields.summary: Git plugin should error out if change detection fails

fields.description:
Currently we still use jgit for some operations even when the git executable exists.  We should use the executable for everything.

We had a case today where half the build was working and half wasn't..
fields.summary: Use native Git when the native git capability is available

fields.description:
The List Authors tab says... "A listing of all authors who commit to..."
The List Users tab says... "A listing of all authors who commit to..."

If both these tabs are worth having, then the distinction between them should be clarified.
fields.summary: User and Author statistics tabs need UI clarification

fields.description:
The author page can be accessed when an author that is not mapped to a Bamboo user is clicked:

http://domain:8085/bamboo/browse/author/user_id

(user_id is the repo user id)

This is the query run:
{code}
select distinct 
abstractre3_.BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_ID
abstractre3_.abstractre3_.BUILD_TYPE 
abstractre3_.CREATED_DATE
abstractre3_.UPDATED_DATE
abstractre3_.BUILD_KEY as BUILD_KEY, 
abstractre3_.BUILD_NUMBER as BUILD_NU6_, 
abstractre3_.BUILD_STATE as BUILD_ST7_, 
abstractre3_.LIFE_CYCLE_STATE as LIFE_CYC8_, 
abstractre3_.BUILD_DATE as BUILD_DATE, 
abstractre3_.BUILD_CANCELLED_DATE as BUILD_C10_, 
abstractre3_.BUILD_COMPLETED_DATE as BUILD_C11_, 
abstractre3_.DURATION as DURATION, 
abstractre3_.PROCESSING_DURATION as PROCESS13_, 
abstractre3_.TIME_TO_FIX as TIME_TO14_, 
abstractre3_.TRIGGER_REASON as TRIGGER15_, 
abstractre3_.DELTA_STATE as DELTA_S16_, 
abstractre3_.BUILD_AGENT_ID as BUILD_A17_, 
abstractre3_.STAGERESULT_ID as STAGERE18_, 
abstractre3_.RESTART_COUNT as RESTART19_, 
abstractre3_.QUEUE_TIME as QUEUE_TIME, 
abstractre3_.MARKED_FOR_DELETION as MARKED_21_, 
abstractre3_.FAILURE_TEST_COUNT as FAILURE22_, 
abstractre3_.SUCCESS_TEST_COUNT as SUCCESS23_, 
abstractre3_.TOTAL_TEST_COUNT as TOTAL_T24_, 
abstractre3_.BROKEN_TEST_COUNT as BROKEN_25_, 
abstractre3_.EXISTING_TEST_COUNT as EXISTIN26_, 
abstractre3_.FIXED_TEST_COUNT as FIXED_T27_, 
abstractre3_.TOTAL_TEST_DURATION as TOTAL_T28_, 
abstractre3_.VCS_UPDATE_TIME as VCS_UPD29_, 
abstractre3_.CHAIN_RESULT as CHAIN_R30_, 
abstractre3_.CONTINUABLE as CONTINU31_ 

from 
BUILD abstractpl0_, 
USER_COMMIT commitimpl1_ 

inner join REPOSITORY_CHANGESET repository2_ 
on commitimpl1_.REPOSITORY_CHANGESET_ID=repository2_.REPOSITORY_CHANGESET_ID 

inner join BUILDRESULTSUMMARY abstractre3_ 
on repository2_.BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_ID=abstractre3_.BUILDRESULTSUMMARY_ID 

where 
(commitimpl1_.AUTHOR_ID=10485761 )AND(abstractre3_.DELTA_STATE='BROKEN' )AND(abstractpl0_.FULL_KEY=abstractre3_.BUILD_KEY )AND(abstractpl0_.abstractre3_.BUILD_TYPE in('BUILD' , 'CHAIN')) 

order by 
abstractre3_.BUILD_DATE DESC;
{code}
fields.summary: Author Page is very ineficient
BuildResultSummary deletion takes huge amount of DB locks and is deadlock prone
Enable/Disable a Plan via REST

fields.description:
We'd like to see the ability to roll back deployments in bamboo and the bamboo jira plugin.
In Bamboo it could be as simple as a button for rerunning successful plans.
fields.summary: Ability to rollback releases/rerun plans

fields.description:
Currently, Bamboo Maven Dependencies does not show correctly if the  pom.xml is configure with variable and the variable is define in Environment Variables in job Task

Example pom.xml:
{code}
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
  xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/maven-v4_0_0.xsd">
  <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>
  <groupId>com.zed.atlassian</groupId>
  <artifactId>zedtry</artifactId>
  <packaging>jar</packaging>
  <version>1.0-SNAPSHOT</version>
  <name>zedtry</name>
    
 <dependencies> 
  <dependency>
  <groupId>maven</groupId>
  <artifactId>dom4j</artifactId>
  <version>${MAVENZED}</version>
 </dependency>
 <dependency>
      <groupId>junit</groupId>
      <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
      <version>3.8.1</version>
      <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
 </dependencies>

</project>
{code}

Configuration of Maven2 task:
!maven_task3.png|thumbnail!

Result of the Maven Dependencies Screen:
!maven_task2.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Maven dependencies does not show correct information for variable

fields.description:
Currently if you click on run customised you get a page talking about what variables are.

There should a be a small description saying what clicking "run" will actually do. e.g. this will run the build with any variable overrides you provide.  

It should also tell you what its going to build (i.e the plan name). This is to disambiguate whether your running a branch/job or plan.
fields.summary: Run Customised Option should tell you what its going to run
